Award.AwardTitle: Graded-Index Metamaterial Waveguides: An Innovative Approach to Acoustic Wave Control

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Acoustic waves play an important role in many applications, such as homeland security (e.g. sonar systems), healthcare (e.g. ultrasound imaging), and industry (e.g., non-destructive damage detections). However, there are currently limited functional acoustic materials that can effectively control and manipulate acoustic waves and be employed for next-generation acoustic-based devices. This award supports fundamental research on guiding, compression, amplification, and localization of acoustic waves through novel artificial acoustic materials (i.e., acoustic metamaterials). These engineered materials possess unique properties that are unachievable in natural materials. This work will open up new avenues towards the development of novel functional acoustic devices, which can potentially overcome the fundamental limitations encountered in conventional acoustic technologies. Various disciplines including physics, material science, medicine, measurement science, and energy sciences will benefit from different facets of this research. This award will also help broaden the participation of underrepresented groups in research and enrich the learning experience of students with innovative projects in an interdisciplinary curriculum integrated with the research findings.

Through combined analytical, numerical, and experimental studies, the goal of this work is to achieve a fundamental understanding of the acoustic wave propagation and guiding mechanisms, material dispersion, effective refractive indices in various graded-index metamaterial waveguides. The largely unexplored properties of these acoustic metamaterials, including the remarkable wave compression and field amplification properties, will be investigated. This research will enrich the knowledge in the growing field of anisotropic metamaterials and lead to new methodologies for control and manipulation of acoustic fields with metamaterials. Furthermore, a novel experimental approach based on a fiber optic acoustic scanning system with graphene based fiber optic probes will be developed, which will offer an entirely new way for mapping and visualization of wave propagation properties in acoustic metamaterials. In addition, this award can also lead to the discovery of fundamentally new physical phenomena in graded-index metamaterial waveguides arrays (bulk graded index metamaterials) in terms of energy coupling, scattering, and localization.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall objective of this project is to achieve a fundamental understanding of graded-index metamaterial waveguides (GIMWs), for guiding, compression, amplification, and localization of acoustic waves, and to explore novel methodologies for control and manipulation of acoustic waves with functional metamaterial devices.  

Intellectual Merits: Fundamental understanding of wave propagation and guiding mechanisms, material dispersion, effective refractive index of low dimensional graded-index metamaterial waveguides has been developed, which will enrich the knowledge in the growing field of anisotropic metamaterials and lead to novel approach for control and manipulation of acoustic fields with metamaterials. The largely unexplored properties of both passive and active low dimensional graded-index metamaterial waveguides have been explored and the remarkable wave compressing and field amplification capabilities of these materials have been discovered. This has opened up new avenues towards the development of novel functional acoustic devices (e.g, acoustic sensors, filters, amplifiers) that can potentially overcome the fundamental limitations encountered in conventional acoustic systems.Furthermore, a novel experimental approach based on a fiber optic acoustic scanning system that makes use of a miniature graphene based fiber optic probe has been developed. This approach renders a new method for mapping and visualization of wave propagation properties insubwavelengthacoustic metamaterialstructures. In addition, the investigation into GIMW arrays has led to new understanding of wave guiding and manipulation using bulk GIMWs. This enables the development of novel acoustic metasurface that can help provide ultra-broadband acoustic absorption for energy dissipation (e.g., shock wave mitigation, noise reduction) or energy harvesting.    

Broader Impacts: Various disciplines including physics, material science, medicine, and energy sciences will benefit from different facets of the proposed research. For example, the proposed fundamental research on GIMWs can potentially lead to transformative developments in acoustic sensing and wave-energy harvesting technologies, which can potentially impact many fronts, including but not limited to safety (e.g. sonar arrays), public health (e.g., ultrasonic imaging), environment and sustainable energy (e.g., high efficiency wave-energy harvester), surveillance (e.g., underwater communication and navigation), and industry (e.g., non-destructive damage detection).

By integrating research with education, the learning experience of students has been enriched with innovative projects in an interdisciplinary curriculum integrated with the findings of this work.The new research results on graphene based fiber optic acoustic probe have been integrated into a senior elective course on fiber optics. Furthermore, this project has involved one post-doctoral researcher, one minority Ph.D. student, one undergraduate student, and one high school student. The project has provided them research experience in terms of acoustic modeling, metamaterial design and fabrication, and hands-on acoustic experiments. The minority Ph.D. student has presented two conference papers the ASME IMECE conference.The postdoc researcher has joined Haerbin Engineering University in China as a Professor.
